And, unless it's urgent, best to pause until everyone on it can engage either by email or in a meeting. I don't know how many times I've seen group emails basically devolve into an ongoing convo between two to three people. And it doesn't serve collaborative efforts well.

Pro-tip for group emails: please, please, PLEASE pay attention to who isn't engaging/responding as much, if not even more, than who is. EACH 👏🏽 ADDITIONAL 👏🏿 EMAIL 👏🏾 requires more time and energy for people to catch up, much less engage.

Maybe I'm asking for too much, but not interested in being friends or in community with folx who are conflict adverse & don't have a practice of individual or communal accountability. I know I'm probably going to be hurt by people I know. I just want to be able to talk about it.

Then I'm not an experienced person with perspective, but just an angry and mean one. Because apparently people who know I try to hold others accountable for the impact of their actions, despite their intent, are suddenly surprised when I do the same thing with them.

I think it's interesting how some people want me to be involved with things related to collective liberation and dismantling systems of oppression because of my experience and perspective, until i grow critical internally.

If this event has happened before, was it better this time? If it's going to happen again, will it be better next time? Who showed up and why? Who didn't and why? Because on a related note I don't believe an org can claim to be doing DEI work, while not asking these questions.

Success shouldn't just be whether a thing happened, but if you achieved your goals. And if your goals are just about attendance, but not the experience for those attending, as well as who isn't attending and why, you are literally valuing quantity while ignoring quality.
Spoiler alert: If you aren't making time to significantly pause and meaningfully debrief after an event, I'm talking at LEAST a 2-hour meeting, then you are probably stuck in #GrindCulture.

But because it's not what you expected, somehow the issue is on my end. Yeah...quickly coming to a breaking point with this and may just have to see myself out of the situation if it doesn't change soon.

Particularly frustrated with someone who "thought we were good", telling me that my emails are curt and that they then feel like they have to "walk on eggshells". No, just thought you'd know we were good and take my emails the same way we talk.

So yeah, definitely a red flag when someone, especially a 🌾 person, offer unsolicited "help", and shuts down if they're told what they THINK is help is neither useful or even helpful, even when asked to actually respond to support that is explicitly requested.

And it's telling that #RealTalk and candid feedback is taken as an attack, and I think is a product of #ToxicPositivity culture. The whole "if you have nothing nice to say..." gets conflated in this, and basically has a silencing effect on people that just want to be direct.

Spoiler alert: saying "no" is not an attack. It's called consent and is communicating a boundary. And it's relevant even when not talking about sex! It's been exhausting being forced to collaborate with someone who clearly isn't used to rejection or even "negative" feedback.

Just another way i think neurodivergent folx get judged or even punished when presumed to be neurotypical. Definitely not a new or original thought, but just what i'm reflecting on at this moment, as my day feels lighter because of a small task I accomplished.

I think it's also interesting reflecting on tension and conflict with supervisors, when expressing needs to help focus and set boundaries have been taken as signs of insubordination, ironically when I'm doing things that i've been told to do.

Fortunately, I'm beginning to recognize this quicker, and remember to give myself grace, as I struggle to navigate this as 40yo who's rarely had the structure and support i've needed in the work place, so why I am holding myself to a higher standard in my personal life.

It never ceases to amaze me how much space small tasks take up in my head at times. And when I finally get to it, through my #ADHD & Executive Dysfunction, the lightness that comes with it, while a relief, also then triggers initial feelings of guilt for not doing it sooner.

Because at this point I don't understand how arts advocacy that isn't fighting for housing & healthcare, or even UBI, among other things is one that has artists explicitly in mind.

Been thinking a lot about the thread I began to unravel at @AM_AU_ is one I've continue to pull at. And definitely hoping to refine a model of arts advocacy, especially in DC, that centers individual artists rather than institutions and administrators.

Artists at our cores make a living out of expressing ourselves. And as someone who had a career being comfortable in the ensemble of stage, even THAT was generally in service of someone else's vision.

Could you imagine if more artists had the abundance of time and energy to advocate for themselves, rather than struggling in and against the grind culture various industries contribute to perpetuating, ESPECIALLY nonprofits?

And that may take different things and different amounts of time on different days. And that's okay. What's particularly relieving is letting go of the idea that I've failed myself, or failed to get my day started, if my morning routine doesn't look a particular way.

Rather, what I've been doing, is having a menu of things I can do in any order, and that I don't necessarily need to do all of them, every time. I think remembering that, in this case, the goal of my routine is to get the day started.

Had a bit of a breakthrough moment for myself and managing my ADHD and the idea of routines in the morning. I realized what works for me is to not think of my morning routine as a constant list of things that I need to do in a particular order.

Ironically marginalized folx who call for accountability are often canceled. Bit this is also the system working exactly the way it's meant to. Maybe that's why many of us try to call & keep people in community, b/c we know what it's like to be demonized to justify a narrative.

And I think a lot of this is informed by conflict adverse versus conflict resilient mindsets, which is related to toxic positivity and false binaries, the main one being that any & everyone that hurts someone else is a bad person. But the truth is often much more complicated.

Not a new or hot take, but definitely tired of how some conflate & confuse "accountability culture" and "cancel culture". 

Cancel culture wants people to be punished and kicked out of community.

Accountability culture wants people to do better and kept in community.

Which is to say allyship & being an ally isn't something you are, but something you do. While there may be some who hold so many privileged identities, they may find themselves being an ally more than not. But I think the many are in some middle ground that requires versatility.

As a member of the queer community, I want het friends and colleagues to be an ally for me, but I also try to be an ally for my bi & pan, and trans & nonbinary friends, without and WITHIN our own community.

Sometimes i wonder how much people think of allyship as relational...like there are times a white male friend might need to be an ally to me re: racism, but then we need to be allies to our friends who are women and femmes.

Thoughts have included even having a bit of a meta Community Engagement event ABOUT what Community Engagement is and means, with other theatre professionals. #DCTheatre

[Also, I haven't been keeping track of what I've been giving throughout the year, so the urgency for End of Year giving is just kind of lost on me.]

Because sometimes, especially when money's tight, it feels like it lands as a bit of a classist microaggression, to presume every who gives, gives enough to include what they give in deductions when taxes come around. And it just reminds me that I don't...every year.

AND it's just not one of the incentives of giving for me. But, especially as a communications and development person, I know it can be for others. Although I do wonder how many people actually do...but I digress. So...yeah segmenting.

Is it selfish to want nonprofits to segment me in communications that DON'T mention my donation being tax-deductible? Like...I know. BUT I also don't think I've ever given enough (much less had so much to give) where my combined deductions total more than the standard deduction.

@karenkr83722210 @WhoopiGoldberg @CBSAllAccess Because with some identities, people who don't belong to that community or have relevant lived experiences can't act the part authentically and (despite intent or learned knowledge) may be leaning on assumptions and stereotypes informed by unconscious bias.

@karenkr83722210 @WhoopiGoldberg @CBSAllAccess Well then trust actors of marginalized identities to be able to tell you that. You can't look at acting and being without looking at equity and oppression.

@conedx @WhoopiGoldberg @CBSAllAccess And even if it did, there are Deaf people that can hear (to varying degrees) and talk, so your own point is uninformed and misguided in terms of what is and isn't possible, regarding actors and characters.

@conedx @WhoopiGoldberg @CBSAllAccess Right, because adaptations of books have never changed plot points or characters. Also from what I know about the plot, making the character not be able to talk and hear for the entire story wouldn't actually significantly affect it.

@TrollishMcTroll @andmorrill And hearing actors will never be able to act as a deaf character as authentically as deaf actors can. Point blank and period. We don't have the lived experience of the language, the culture, the communities. And if we're committed to anti-audism and equity, we wouldn't try.

@TrollishMcTroll @andmorrill "The point of acting" is often a referred to talking point that I often wonder what people mean when they say it. In this case it seems to imply that acting is about faking it, whereas in this context acting is about portraying a character authentically.

@TrollishMcTroll @andmorrill Those barriers can include unconscious bias in general, casting directors not realizing when they're making decisions based on stereotypes, or even deaf and hard of hearing actors not even being brought in to audition (like in this situation).

@TrollishMcTroll @andmorrill It's less that you can't if you aren't, but more that you are complicit in the oppression of marginalized identities and those with relevant lived experiences, who are better able to play the part but often aren't cast because of barriers due to said oppression.
